title: 113_hr1128
content: The Act titled "Protecting U.S. Missile Defense Information Act of 2013" requires reports and briefings on missile defense discussions between the United States and the Russian Federation. The President must submit a semi-annual report to Congress on missile defense discussions with Russia, including dates, officials involved, summaries of discussions, and exchanged documents. The initial report is due within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The President must submit a semi-annual report to Congress on missile defense discussions with Russia, including dates, officials involved, summaries of discussions, and exchanged documents. The reports must be in unclassified form but may have a classified annex if necessary. The President must also brief the congressional defense committees on the report and related matters. SEC. 3. REPORTS AND BRIEFINGS ON DECLASSIFICATION OF CERTAIN MISSILE DEFENSE INFORMATION. The President must submit a semi-annual report to Congress on meetings of the National Disclosure Policy Committee regarding declassifying documents on US missile defense systems. The report should include meeting dates, document descriptions, Committee determinations on declassification, and reasoning summaries. The initial report is due within 180 days. The reports required by subsection (a) must be submitted within 180 days in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. The President is also required to brief congressional defense committees on the report's contents and related matters. SEC. 4 and SEC. 5 limit funds for providing Russia with missile defense technology and negotiating agreements on US missile defense capabilities. Congress declares that the United States shall not be bound by any executive agreement related to missile defense capabilities, including basing, locations, and numbers of missiles. No funds for the Department of Defense can be used to negotiate or implement such agreements or to enforce rules of engagement or guidance related to them. The section defines an executive agreement as an international agreement that is not a treaty or does not require implementing legislation. It also states that funds cannot be used to negotiate or implement executive agreements with countries under a treaty of alliance or security guarantee. SEC. 6. DISCLOSURE OF AND REPORT ON RUSSIAN FEDERATION SUPPORT OF BALLISTIC MISSILE DEFENSE PROGRAMS OF CHINA, SYRIA, IRAN, AND NORTH KOREA. The President is required to encourage Russia to disclose any support for ballistic missile programs of China, Syria, Iran, or North Korea. A semi-annual report must be submitted to Congress on any disclosed support. The initial report should cover the 10-year period leading up to the enactment of this Act. The report required by subsection (b) shall be submitted in unclassified form, with the option of including a classified annex if necessary. SEC. 7. Defines "congressional defense committees" as per section 101(a)(16) of title 10, United States Code.
